div.l: Whan þat oure host hadde herd þis ʆsermonyng
He gan for to speke as lordly as a kyng
He seide what amounteth al þis witte
What shal we speke al day of holy writte
The deuel made a Reue for to p̉reche
Or of a souter a shipman or a leche
Sey forth thy tale and tarie nouȝt þe tyme
Lo depford and it is almost pⁱrime
Lo Grenewych þat many a shrewe is ynne
It were al tyme þi tale to bigynne
Now sires qduod þis Oswold þe reue
I pray ȝow alle þᵗat ȝe nought ȝow greue
Though I answere ⁊and somdel sette his howe
For leefful it is wᵗith force · force of showe
This dronke Miller hath y tolde vs here
How þat begyled was a carpentere
Par aunter in scorne for þᵗat I am oon
And by ȝoure leue I shal hym quite anoon
Right in his cherles t̉ermes wol I speke
I prey to god his nekke mote to breke
He can wel in myn eye seen a stalke
But in his owne he can not seen a balke
¶ Explicit ꝓprologus
et Incipit fabula
AT Trumpyngtoıı̄un nouȝt fer fro Caumbrigge
Ther goth a brook · and ouer þat a brigge
Vpon þe which brook þer stant a melle
And þis is verray soth þᵗat I ȝow telle
A meller was þere dwellynge many a day
As eny pecok he was proud and gay
Pipen he couthe and fisshen and nettes bete
And torne coppes ⁊and wel wrastle and shete
Ay by his belt he bar a long panade
And of a swerd ful trenchant was þe blade
A ioly popper bar he in his powche
Ther was no man for ꝑperile dorste hȳm touche
A schefeld thwytel bar he in his hose
Round was his face and camuse was his nose
As piled as an ape was his sculle
He was a market beter atte fulle
